name: Triangle Sum Theorem
statement: The sum of the angles in a triangle is 180°.
philosophy: Foundation of triangle geometry.

name: Exterior Angle Theorem
statement: An exterior angle is equal to the sum of the two remote interior angles.
philosophy: Used in angle calculations.

name: Isosceles Triangle Base Angles
statement: In an isosceles triangle, the base angles are equal.
philosophy: Fundamental symmetry property.

name: Equilateral Triangle Angles
statement: Each angle in an equilateral triangle is 60°.
philosophy: Used in regular triangle arguments.

name: AA Similarity
statement: Two triangles are similar if two corresponding angles are equal.
philosophy: Used to prove similarity.

name: SAS Similarity
statement: Two triangles are similar if two sides are proportional and the included angles are equal.
philosophy: Establishes triangle similarity.

name: Right Triangle Altitude Rule
statement: In a right triangle, the altitude to the hypotenuse forms two similar triangles.
philosophy: Used in many geometric ratios.

name: Angle in a Semicircle
statement: An angle inscribed in a semicircle is a right angle.
formal: If AB is a diameter and C on circle, ∠ACB = 90°
philosophy: Classical circle property.

name: Inscribed Angle Theorem
statement: An inscribed angle is half the measure of its intercepted arc.
philosophy: Key angle-arc relationship.

name: Angles in Same Segment
statement: Angles subtended by the same chord are equal.
formal: If arc AC subtends ∠ABC and ∠ADC, then ∠ABC = ∠ADC
philosophy: Cyclic property in circles.

name: Cyclic Quadrilateral Opposite Angles
statement: In a cyclic quadrilateral, opposite angles sum to 180°.
philosophy: Classic property of cyclic quads.

name: Power of a Point (Secant-Tangent)
statement: For a point outside a circle, PA² = PB·PC.
philosophy: Used in circle power calculations.

name: Power of a Point (Chord-Chord)
statement: For chords AB and CD intersecting at E, AE·EB = CE·ED.
philosophy: Used with intersecting chords.

name: Intersecting Chords Theorem
statement: The product of segments of intersecting chords are equal.
philosophy: Same as chord-chord power.

name: Equal Tangents Theorem
statement: Tangents from a common external point to a circle are equal in length.
formal: If PA and PB are tangents, then PA = PB
philosophy: Tangents form equal lengths.

name: Angle Bisector Theorem
statement: An angle bisector divides the opposite side in the ratio of the adjacent sides.
philosophy: Used in ratio arguments.

name: Median to Hypotenuse
statement: In a right triangle, the median to the hypotenuse is half its length.
formal: If M is midpoint of hypotenuse AB, then CM = ½ AB
philosophy: Used in midpoint-based proofs.

name: Centroid Ratio
statement: The centroid divides each median in a 2:1 ratio.
philosophy: Used in center-of-mass arguments.

name: Incenter Touches Sides
statement: The incenter is equidistant from all triangle sides.
formal: ID = IE = IF (where D, E, F are feet)
philosophy: Used in circle incenter problems.

name: Nine Point Circle
statement: Passes through midpoints, feet of altitudes, and midpoints from orthocenter.
philosophy: Advanced center property.

name: Shoelace Formula
statement: For a polygon with vertices (x₁, y₁), (x₂, y₂), ..., (xₙ, yₙ) listed in order, the area is ½ × |Σ(xᵢyᵢ₊₁ − xᵢ₊₁yᵢ)| with indices cyclic.
formal: Area = ½ × abs(cross sum over cyclic indices)
philosophy: Standard method for computing area of polygons using coordinates.

name: Distance Formula
statement: Distance between (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) is √[(x2−x1)² + (y2−y1)²]
philosophy: Used in analytic geometry.

name: Area-Height-Base Relation (Bidirectional)
statement: In any triangle, the area equals half the product of a base and its corresponding height. Conversely, the height equals twice the area divided by the base.
formal:
A = (1/2) 	imes 	ext{base} 	imes 	ext{height};
	ext{height} = (2 	imes A) / 	ext{base}
philosophy: Fundamental relation connecting area, base, and height in both directions.

name: Area using Sine
statement: A = ½ab sin(C)
philosophy: Used in angle-based area problems.

name: Area using Heron’s Formula
philosophy: Used when all sides known.

name: Pythagorean Theorem
statement: In a right triangle, a² + b² = c²
philosophy: Foundation of right triangle geometry.

name: Pythagorean Converse
statement: If a² + b² = c², then triangle is right.
philosophy: Used to prove right angle.

name: Similarity Proportions
statement: Corresponding sides of similar triangles are proportional.
philosophy: Used in ratio problems.

name: Altitude Area Splitting
statement: An altitude divides triangle into two smaller ones of equal height.
formal: Area = ½ base × height applies to both.
philosophy: Used in triangle composition.

name: Radius to Tangent Perpendicular
statement: A radius is perpendicular to a tangent at point of contact.
philosophy: Circle-tangent intersection rule.

name: Tangent-Chord Angle
statement: Angle between a tangent and a chord is half the intercepted arc.
philosophy: Used in mixed angle problems.

name: Box Side Center
statement: The center of a rectangular face in 3D space is the midpoint of its diagonal.
formal: Center = midpoint of diagonal connecting opposite corners
philosophy: Defines the center of a box face via 3D coordinate geometry.

name: Area of Triangle from Vectors (3D)
statement: The area of a triangle in 3D is half the magnitude of the cross product of two side vectors.
philosophy: Computes area from triangle vectors in 3D space.

name: Parameterization of a Line Segment
statement: A line segment from point A to point B in 3D space can be parameterized as (1-t)A + tB, where 0 ≤ t ≤ 1.
philosophy: Expresses any point on a line segment using a parameter t ranging from 0 to 1.

name: Parameterization of a Line (3D)
statement: A line through a point A in 3D space in the direction of a vector v can be parameterized as A + tv, where t is any real number.
formal: (x, y, z) = (x1 + td_x, y1 + td_y, z1 + td_z), t ∈ ℝ
philosophy: Expresses a line in 3D space using a base point and a direction vector scaled by a real parameter.

name: Parameterization of a Plane (3D)
statement: A plane in 3D space through a point A with spanning vectors u and v can be parameterized as A + su + tv, where s and t are real numbers.
philosophy: Expresses every point on a plane using two independent direction vectors from a base point.

name: Triangle Congruence (SSS)
statement: Two triangles are congruent if their corresponding sides are equal in length.
formal: If AB = DE, BC = EF, AC = DF, then △ABC ≅ △DEF
philosophy: Foundational rule for proving triangles congruent using side lengths.

name: Triangle Congruence (SAS)
statement: Two triangles are congruent if two sides and the included angle are respectively equal.
formal: If AB = DE, AC = DF, and ∠A = ∠D, then △ABC ≅ △DEF
philosophy: Fundamental rule for triangle congruence based on two sides and included angle.

name: Triangle Congruence (ASA)
statement: Two triangles are congruent if two angles and the included side are respectively equal.
philosophy: Establishes triangle congruence based on two angles and the included side.

name: Volume of a Tetrahedron
statement: The volume of a tetrahedron with adjacent vectors u, v, w is one-sixth the absolute value of the scalar triple product.
philosophy: Calculates 3D volume from vectors at a vertex.

name: Ptolemy's Theorem (Cyclic Quadrilateral)
statement: In a cyclic quadrilateral, the product of the diagonals equals the sum of the products of the opposite sides.
philosophy: Relates sides and diagonals in cyclic quadrilaterals, essential for advanced circle geometry.

name: Brahmagupta's Formula (Cyclic Quadrilateral Area)
statement: The area of a cyclic quadrilateral with sides a, b, c, d is √[(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)(s-d)], where s = (a+b+c+d)/2.
philosophy: Generalizes Heron's formula for cyclic quadrilaterals, connecting side lengths to area.

name: Menelaus' Theorem
statement: In a triangle, if a transversal cuts across the sides (or extensions), the product of ratios of divided segments equals 1.
philosophy: Connects line intersections in a triangle via ratios.

name: Stewart's Theorem
statement: In triangle ABC with point D on BC, AD² = AB²·(DC/BC) + AC²·(BD/BC) - BD·DC.
philosophy: Relates side lengths and cevian segments in a triangle.

name: Gergonne Point
statement: The point of concurrency of lines from the vertices to the points of tangency of the incircle with the opposite sides.
formal: Gergonne Point exists for any triangle.
philosophy: Describes the concurrency related to the triangle’s incircle.

name: Triangle Congruence (AAS)
statement: Two triangles are congruent if two angles and a non-included side are respectively equal.
philosophy: Establishes triangle congruence based on two angles and a non-included side.

name: Extended Law of Sines
statement: In any triangle ABC with circumradius R, a / sin A = b / sin B = c / sin C = 2R.
formal: a / sin A = b / sin B = c / sin C = 2R
philosophy: Connects side lengths and angles through the triangle's circumradius.

name: Ceva's Theorem
statement: In triangle ABC, points D, E, F are on BC, AC, and AB respectively. Lines AD, BE, and CF concur if and only if (BD/DC) × (CE/EA) × (AF/FB) = 1.
philosophy: Characterizes when three cevians are concurrent inside a triangle via ratios.

name: Law of Sines
statement: In any triangle ABC, the ratio of the length of a side to the sine of its opposite angle is the same for all three sides.
formal: a / sin A = b / sin B = c / sin C
philosophy: Connects side lengths and angles in any triangle.

name: Law of Cosines
statement: In any triangle ABC, the square of one side equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides minus twice their product times the cosine of the included angle.
philosophy: Generalizes the Pythagorean theorem to arbitrary triangles.

name: Mass Point Geometry: Weight Ratios
statement: In a triangle with mass points assigned to vertices, the ratios of divided segments are inversely proportional to the masses.
formal: If mass(A):mass(B) = d(BE):d(AE), then m(A)d(AE) = m(B)d(BE)
philosophy: Simplifies ratio problems by assigning masses to vertices.

name: Inversion Definition
statement: Under inversion with center O and radius r, point P maps to P' such that OP·OP' = r².
philosophy: Defines the basic relation of inversion based on fixed distance product.

name: Reflection Across a Line
statement: The reflection of a point P across a line ℓ is the point P' such that ℓ is the perpendicular bisector of segment PP'.
formal: Line ℓ is ⟂ bisector of segment PP'
philosophy: Defines reflection operation over a line as an isometric mapping.

name: Pythagorean Identity
statement: sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1 for all real θ.
philosophy: This identity reflects the unit circle definition of sine and cosine.

name: Cosine Double Angle
statement: cos(2θ) = 2cos²(θ) − 1 = 1 − 2sin²(θ)
philosophy: Relates angle doubling to squared trig functions.

name: Sine Double Angle
statement: sin(2θ) = 2sin(θ)cos(θ)
philosophy: Expresses angle doubling in terms of base functions.

name: Cosine Angle Sum
statement: cos(A + B) = cos A cos B − sin A sin B
philosophy: Foundation for general angle manipulations.

name: Tangent Double Angle Formula
statement: tan(2θ) = 2tan(θ) / (1 - tan²(θ))
philosophy: Derived from the sine and cosine double angle formulas, this identity allows transformation of a tangent function of double angle into terms of the single angle.

name: Exact Value of cos(36°)
statement: The exact value of cos(36°) is (√5 + 1) / 4.
philosophy: This identity arises in regular pentagon geometry and golden ratio constructions. It allows reasoning involving classic angle values in Euclidean geometry.

name: Complex Point Representation
statement: A point in the plane can be represented as a complex number z = x + yi.
formal: z = x + yi, where x and y are real
philosophy: Encodes planar geometry using complex numbers for algebraic manipulation.

name: Distance via Complex Modulus
statement: The distance between two points z₁ and z₂ is |z₁ − z₂|.
philosophy: Uses modulus to compute Euclidean distance between complex points.

name: Rotation via Complex Multiplication
statement: Rotating point z about the origin by angle θ counterclockwise is z ↦ z·e^{iθ}.
philosophy: Encodes rotations as complex multiplication; simplifies angular movement.

name: Reflection via Conjugation
statement: Reflecting a point z across the real axis gives its complex conjugate z̄.
philosophy: Models geometric reflection using complex conjugation.

name: Collinearity Condition (Complex)
statement: Points A, B, C are collinear if (A−B)/(B−C) is real.
philosophy: Determines collinearity through complex ratio; key tool in algebraic geometry proofs.

name: Radical Axis Theorem
statement: Given two circles, the set of points with equal power to both is a straight line called the radical axis.
formal: Power(P, ω₁) = Power(P, ω₂) ⇒ P lies on the radical axis
philosophy: Defines the locus of points equidistant in power from two circles. Fundamental for intersection geometry.

name: Euler Line Collinearity
statement: In any non-equilateral triangle, the orthocenter (H), centroid (G), and circumcenter (O) are collinear, with GH = 2·GO.
formal: O, G, H collinear with GH = 2·GO
philosophy: Describes the alignment of classical triangle centers; foundational in triangle center geometry.

name: Homothety and Dilation
statement: A homothety centered at point O with ratio k maps each point P to P' such that OP' = k·OP and P, O, P' are collinear.
formal: Homothety_O^k(P) = P' with OP'/OP = k, P, O, P' collinear
philosophy: Models similarity transformations from a fixed center; powerful for tangent and circle problems.

name: Trigonometric Identity: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1 and Symmetry
statement: For any angle θ in degrees, sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1. Also, for any θ, sin²(θ) + sin²(90° − θ) = 1.
philosophy: Unifies Pythagorean identity and cofunction symmetry; used for averaging symmetric sine square terms.

name: Complex Multiplication as Rotation and Dilation
statement: In the complex plane, multiplication by a complex number z = re^{iθ} rotates a point about the origin by angle θ and scales it by a factor r.
philosophy: Complex multiplication has geometric meaning: rotation and dilation centered at the origin. This enables reasoning about z, z², z³ as progressively rotated points.

name: Shoelace Area Formula for Complex Points
statement: Given complex numbers z₁, z₂, ..., zₙ representing polygon vertices in order, the signed area A is (1/2)·Im(z₁·conj(z₂) + z₂·conj(z₃) + ... + zₙ·conj(z₁)).
philosophy: Generalizes the shoelace formula using complex multiplication and conjugation. Enables area computation from ordered complex vertices.
